ADDRESS BY DOCTOR ANTONIO DIAZ ALBERTINI, DIRECTOR OF “LAS ANIMAS”
HOSPITAL AND PRESIDENT OF THE “FINLAY” INSTITUTE, TO HONOR THE MEMORIES OF
DOCTOR JESSE W. LAZEAR AND MISS CLARA MAASS, SEPTEMBER 28, 1936.

The Finlay Institute, created to honor the memory of our glorious
countryman, fulfills today a sacred duty and insofar as possible pays a debt
of gratitude of long standing, honoring in this simple but transcendental
ceremony the memories of those who, like Lazear and Miss Maass, contributed
with their talent and heroism to confirm the discovery of the grand Cuban
genius whose name is a glorious seal for our Institute.

Here in “Las Animas”, seat of immortal findings and experiments of
great scientific value, will harbor from today those plaques which will remind
future generations of the glory, heroism and martyrdom to science and duty of
those two great ones, Lazear and Miss Clara Maass, so deserving of our reverent
remembrance.

Dr. Lazear was one of the first victims of yellow fever during the
experimental epoch of the American Commission of 1900, formed by Doctors Walter
Reed, James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear and Aristides Agramonte. Reed was Pres-
ident and Director of the Commission; Carroll had charge of bacteriological
investigations; Lazear, all that referred to mosquitoes, Agramonte being the
pathologist. The Commission selected for its experiments a pasture field in
Quemados de Marianao to which was later given the name of “Camp Lazear”, in
memory of his name.

Lazear arrived in Cuba months before Reed and Carroll and devoted his
time to the observation of yellow fever cases and to the performing of autopsies.
I witnessed in Dr. Finlay's house, No. 110 Aguacate Street, the presentation of
the Commission to the great Cuban sage, who delivered to Dr. Reed a small soap-
dish with eggs of Stegomya which ten days before had bitten a case of yellow
fever.. While Dr. Reed was absent in the United States, Lazear allowed an infected
mosquito, which had rested on his hand, to bite him. This happened here in this
historic yellow fever ward on September 13, 1900. On the night of the 17th,
that is to say, on the fifth day, he had a chill, followed by others. The ill-
ustrious patient was transferred to the Yellow Fever Isolation Camp. During the
first three days he fought bravely but on the fourth day he succumbed to the
terribly poisonous “black vomit”. Such was the end of Lazear; thus terminating,
at the age of 34, a life of brilliant promise, great aptitude, nobility of
character and an indefatigable worker.

Lazear died before the Yellow Fever Commission terminated its work.
For this reason his signature appears only on the Preliminary Note on the Eti-
ology of Yellow Fever but as Dr. Barnet says in an article about the Commission,
his premature demise deprived him of the great share which would have been his
in the amazing results obtained by the Commission, but there is no room to
doubt that his heroic and most useful act was a contributing factor in the
final results. His remains were interred in the Military Cemetery at Camp Col-
umbia and later on transferred to the London Park Cemetery, Baltimore.

We should remember certain facts in connection with experimental yellow
fever contained in the memorandum published by Dr. Guiteras in “American Medicine”,
where Dr. Guiteras explains that the favorable results obtained by the Commission
in their yellow fever experiments, the continued series of mild cases resulting
therefrom, suggested the idea of continuing this work, not with the object of
proving or rectifying the conclusions of the Commission, in view of the fact that
we considered them sufficiently proved, but with the purpose of spreading the
disease in a controllable form and to obtain immunity in this way, with the least
risk to the individual and to the community.

It was hoped that the results would be favorable, due to the series of
mild cases produced by the Commission. Limitation of the number of bites would
-- 2 --
be a factor, that is to say, the subject would be bitten once by infected
mosquitoes while in the ordinary course, in an infected house for example,
the individual would be exposed to successive bites. Also, the subject
would be under observation during period of incubation and from the moment
of attack he would be under treatment from the start, under mosquito-proof
shelter, thus avoiding risk of spreading the disease.

Having these advantageous conditions in mind, the Chief Sanitary
Officer of Havana, Major W. C. Gorgas, Medical Corps, U. S. Army, decided
to establish an Inoculation Station in “Las Animas” Hospital. The approval
and support of General Wood was obtained, greatly contributing to the
success of the investigations. The Station, with its laboratory, was placed
under the direction of Dr. Guiteras. A Commission, composed of Doctors
Finlay, Gorgas, Diaz Albertini and Ross, the latter being Director of “Las
Animas” Hospital, was formed to cooperate with Dr. Guiteras in the experi-
mental work. The Inoculation Station was inaugurated in February, 1901.

In August of that year, Miss Clara Maass, a native of Orange,
N. J., single, 25 years of age, a nurse employed at the Hospital (“Las
Animas”) voluntarily submitted to be bitten by an infected mosquito. She why?
had resided in Cuba for ten months and had been previously bitten by
mosquitoes five times, without results. On August 14th, at 9:00 A. M., she
was bitten by two of the Alvarez mosquitoes which had previously infected
Represa, the latter having happily recovered. She developed yellow fever
on August 18th, without any prior symptoms. Her temperature had commenced
to rise, accompanied by headache and a slight chill. She had several hemo-
rrages, succumbing to the disease on the seventh day, that is to say, Aug-
ust 24, 1901.

Those are, ladies and gentlemen, expressed in a concise manner,
the salient notes in the admirable lives of Miss Maass and Dr. Lazear who
left us as a legacy the highest examples of abnegation, of sacrifice and
love of science, in which they offered their useful existence for the good
and progress of medicine. And in these moments in which we are honored
with the visit of Dr. Edgar E. Hume, Lieutenant-Colonel of the U. S. Army
Medical Corps, who represents his comrades of the Military Sanitation of
North America, we consider as opportune and in which to render, in the name
of the “Finlay” Institute, a tribute of remembrance and of gratitude to the
memory of Lazear and Miss Maass; placing in this Hospital plaques which
perpetuate the heroism of those cherished martyrs to science.

We desire to demonstrate by this act that we remember Lazear and
Miss Maass and that we equally cherish a loving remembrance of the Doctors
of the American Army who composed the Yellow Fever Commission presided over
by Dr. Walter Reed and of which Doctors Carroll, Lazear and our own great
Agramonte formed part. That there shall live in our hearts, with firmest
sympathies, Gorgas, Kean, Havard, Ross and their companions who ably and
disinterestedly had charge and direction of sanitary affairs in Cuba during
the first American intervention.

To all, our affection and remembrances and we request Dr. Hume to
accept and transmit to his companions of the Army our kindly sentiments and
eternal recognition of the work they accomplished in the sanitation of our
country, including the members of the Army Medical Corps who rendered
valuable services in Cuba from 1899 to 1902, as well as during the days
of the Provisional Government.
